Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of bearded warrior ('Persian rider') wearing pointed helmet, carrying shield and sword. Bottom half missing, as is the horse he most likely rode. Crudely made. Mould-made and solid with crude back. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
'112' written in pencil on the back, more likely a catalogue number than a findspot reference.

Crude cavalry figures are commonly found in the Delta in Late Period or early Ptolemaic contexts and generally dated to the 4th and sometimes as late as the 3rd century BC. They vary greatly from small crude figures (British Museum EA 1886,0802.63), such as those from Naukratis (British Museum Higgins 1954, 407, GR 1886,0401.1468), to more complicated examples with a mould made Persian style rider. This is probably of the latter type. Many parallels found at Naukratis (British Museum GR 1888,0601.90; Cairo SR5/966, CG43442= TR14/9/18/17= SR5/1062, CG 32804; Cambridge MCA NA595, NA603, NA604, NA618, NA619), Tanis (Dunand 1990, 215-6, Cat. 583-592 and 594-595, particularly 583 and 590-2), Memphis (Cairo CG43519= TR15/3/22/16= SR5/1018; SR5/6260; Petrie 1909a, pl.40, nos 42, 46, particularly 46 that may be from the same mould; Petrie 1909b, pl.29; Petrie 1910, pl.42, no.139), Tell Basta (Cairo National Museum CG32810 SR5/967), Zagazig/Bubastis (Cairo TR26/11/22/2=SR5/1073), Tukh el-Karamus (CG32806 JE35660 SR5/895), Deir el Bakari (CG32807 JE36203 SR5/896, CG32808 JE36203 SR5/897), Alexandria (Fischer 1994, nos.20-21) and without provenance (Cairo National Museum SR5/970 CG32907, ST5/969 CG32904, TR22/11/22/1 SR5/906, TR22/11/22/2 SR5/907, TR22/11/22/3 SR5/908, C32902 SR5/898, TR26/11/22/3= SR5/1058, JE/CG32903= SR5/1059). The horse, being hand-made, is slightly different in each case. Figurines of this type are often called ‘Persian riders’ because of their sharp-crested headgear and ‘Asiatic’ beards. They are dated by various scholars to between the 7th or 6th century BC (Edgar in Hogarth et. al. 1905, 129; Petrie 1909a, pl. 40), the mid 4th (Higgins 1954, 407, no. 1549) and the 4th to 3rd century BC (Dunand 1990, 215-6, nos 583-589, 591, particularly 591 and 585). Achaemenid terracotta ‘Persian riders’ found at Dura Europos are similar in style and were made using the same technique (Downey 2003, 142-53, no.91). Parallels from Uruk are dated 999BC-500BC (Ziegler 1963, pl.39, nos 484-9, see also horses and riders pls 40-42, nos 482-536) and Nippur dated broadly 600BC - 300BC, but specifically Persian, c.500BC and a date before 450BC (McCown 1967, pls 47-49, nos 245-262 especially pl. 47, no.245). This suggests one should associate these with the Achaemenid rule of Egypt between 525BC and 332BC. Hogarth cites Cypriot and Phoenician parallels for the ‘Persian rider’ type and other crude limestone and terracotta horsemen found at Naukratis (Edgar in Hogarth et al. 1905, 129). One example from Naukratis (Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology, MCA, NA603) appears to be from the same mould as another example found at Memphis (Petrie 1909, pl.40, no. 46), suggesting that these were transported up and down the Nile branches.
